utterances: That's Daniel Kurtzer.
He was the U.S.
ambassador to Israel from 2001 to 2005.
He spoke to us from Princeton University, where he is now a professor of Middle East policy studies.
Dan Kurtzer, thank you.
Thank you, Guy.
Before the Six-day War of 1967, Israel's de-facto Eastern border was along an armistice line from 1949, the so-called Green Line.
That line is more or less the border that Palestinians hope to make permanent in any final peace deal.
But in the four decades since Israel occupied land beyond that Green Line, nearly half-a-million Israelis have settled in that territory.
Whole Israeli cities have sprung up in the West Bank, and Israel says it would unrealistic to move them out.
But Palestinians say that doesn't matter.
They insist those settlements are illegal, and so dismantling those settlement cities will almost certainly have to happen, they say.
Here's Maen Rashid Areikat.
He is the chief Palestinian representative to Washington.
The Palestinian position has always been that we need to know what the borders of a future Palestinian state.
We cannot negotiate about the establishment of a Palestinian state if we don't know the borders.
And this is something that Israel has been trying to avoid.
When you talk about borders, is there a sense of what might be acceptable, what is in the realm of possibility from the Palestinian perspective?
I mean, could you envision Israel holding on to some of those large settlements that are currently in the occupied territory?
Our position is very clear on borders.
We said 1967 lines with minor modifications.
We absolutely are not envisioning the land swap that the Israelis have been proposing - the five, six percent.
We are talking about as little, as minor as possible of a land swap to accommodate certain interests and changes.
But we are not envisioning a large land swap.
I'm curious to get a sense of what you make of the president's tone.
Is this president seen as somebody who is perhaps friendlier to Palestinians than his predecessor or previous presidents?

I believe that the president has shown from day one his genuine, sincere commitment to advance the peace process between the Israelis and the Palestinians by picking a special envoy who unfortunately resigned a week ago.
And he continues, despite all the difficult challenges this his administration has faced, he continues to be committed to pursuing peace between the Israelis and the Palestinians.
So we are encouraged.
We appreciate the effort of the president and the administration, and we hope that it will lead to something soon.
The president said that negotiations have to happen between the two parties.
But it is your view that that can't really happen without the United States pushing the two parties to the table?
Can it happen without U.S.
involvement?
I think any agreement has to be accepted by both parties.
It has to be a bilateral agreement.
But even getting to the table?
It's because of the inequality.
I mean, the two parties are not equal.
You know, you have an occupying power, and you're having an occupied people.
Tell me about the Palestinian plan to go to the United Nations this fall to seek recognition for a state.
The U.S.
opposes this.
Israel obviously opposes it.
Walk me through the Palestinian thinking on this.
Is it that we have nothing to lose and we might as well do it?
No, it's not that.

I think you just heard the president at AIPAC saying that the Palestinians' inclination to go to the United Nations is because of their impatience, frustration that the bilateral tract, the so-called peace process, did not produce the end of the Israeli military occupation and the establishment of a Palestinian state.
The Palestinian leadership is responsible for its people.
They have to deliver an end to the occupation.
It is not the only option for us.
We have said that repeatedly.
The political process remains to be our first option, but you have to put that in a context that will succeed.
That's Maen Rashid Areikat.
He is the Palestinian Liberation Organization's ambassador to Washington.
He joined me here in the studio.
Ambassador Areikat, thank you so much for coming in.
Thank you very much.
Half of all Americans who work for private companies are employed by small businesses, and small businesses accounted for nearly two-thirds of all new hires between 1993 and 2008.
So, are small businesses hiring now?
This week we're going to pose that question to some business owners.
And today, we're joined by George Lessmeister from Indianapolis.
He's the president of LGC Associates.
Thats a company that provides staffing for the hospitality and food service industries.
Welcome to the program.
Thank you.
And why dont you explain your business just a little bit - the kinds of workers that you're getting placed in jobs.
Well, LGC, we're a hospitality and food service staffing company, such as you mentioned.

And the type of workers that we provide would run anywhere from cooks, banquet servers, bartenders, chefs - anybody that would operate within the front of house or back of the house within the food preparation and serving.
And then we also staff for hotels in roles such as housekeeping, front desk and the administrative functions within a hotel property.
Okay.
And when you think about the last couple of years in this recession, whats business been like for you?
Well, I think obviously the last part of 2008 and the beginning of 2009 were challenging.
But what youve seen this year is our revenues, year-to-date, are running ahead of what they were for the same period in 2009.
We're still slightly ticking below what we did for the same period in 2008 but that gap is starting to shrink a little bit.
What was the lowest point for your business during the recession?
How bad did things get for you?
Well, I think if you look at the beginning part of 2009, that first quarter, that was really tough.
You know, we had to make a lot of difficult cuts and changes and we retracted a lot.
But I think it's made us a stronger company going forward.
You know, it was - that first quarter of 2009 was definitely the biggest challenge that we faced.
How deep were those cuts?
We probably cut back about 50 percent of our internal workforce.
So...
Fifty, five-O?
Five-zero, yes.
Wow, thats a lot.
It was a...
(Soundbite of laughter)
It was significant cuts.
It didnt come without pain.
You know, we recognized maybe we had some replication of duties, maybe we had some people that weren't producing at the levels that they were capable of.
It was tough but, you know, you have to do what you have to do to be able to go forward and be profitable.
And thats - we were not going to fail.
Have you been able to replace or rehire any of those folks that you laid-off?
Yeah.
I mean, what we've looked at is you go on a branch by branch basis.
And we have done some hiring this year.
We did some hiring at the end of fourth quarter in 2009.
But we're more strategic about it.
Each person that comes in should be generating X-amount of revenue to support their position in the company.
And I think that accountability has made everybody better.
So 50 percent cut in the number of workers you had in-house for LGC.
What about the number for workers that you were able to place - how much down was that at the worst part of the recession?
What I can go by is the number of W2s that we generated.
For 2008, we generated about 7,200 W2s.
And for 2009, I think it was around 5,600.
So there was definitely an impact in our temporary workforce, as well.
Well, Mr. Lessmeister, as you look forward, how confident are you in the economy as you see it?
Or are you hedging your bets a bit, thinking, we're not out of this recession yet, we might be heading back down?
Well, Im cautiously optimistic.
I mean, I think, like anything, you're always fearful of how new laws are going to impact your business and how it's going to affect hiring.
But you try not to let that get into your thought process of what you have to accomplish on a daily basis.
You mentioned new laws.
What new laws might you be concerned about?
Well, I mean, obviously there's a health care legislation that passed, and it's going to put new requirements on employers in the coming years.
And you never know how - if companies are going to be skittish about adding incremental workers or how thats going to impact us down the road.
You always get concerned about that.
But again, like I said, we just want to stay focused on what we can control.
Mr.
Lessmeister, thanks for talking to us.
Thank you.
That's George Lessmeister.
He's the president of LGC Associates in Indianapolis.
Politically, Shaked is part of the religious Zionist Jewish Home Party, which draws its strength from Israeli settlers who live in the West Bank.
Negotiations with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu just to name her justice minister were drawn out and difficult.
Jerusalem Post's chief political correspondent, Gil Hoffman, says in part that's because the justice minister wields real power.
